title: Spool holder for Prusa i3 with aluminium frame

description.text: A spool holder to attach to the aluminium frame of the Prusa i3 to have the filament over the printer :)

• Print parts:

    • 2 x Bearing_Support
    • 2 x Frame_Support

  • Mount it (See pictures, it's easy), you need:

    • 4 x 2cm M3 screws
    • 4 x M3 nuts
    • 4 x M8 nuts
    • 2 x 608zz Bearings
    • 3 x Threaded rods about 15 cms each

  • Mount spool and print!

  • Be happy! :)

comments.text: Hey. Great design.  Thanks.  Been using mine for close to a year.
comments.author: AbbyJones

comments.text:
Easy to print, easy to mount, easy to use.
Non printable parts are easy to find.
Using a prusa I3, I wouldn't recommend another spool holder, except if you wish to transform your printer into a rocket with very sophisticated designs !!
Add Fabsterdam idea to the whole thing (see below) and you're set for years
Adapted to ~6mm thick frames

comments.text: Nice :) Is there any problem with spool movements when the extruder go far to the right or left ?

comments.author: wawok

comments.text: The threaded rod holding the spool rotates continually in the same direction as it is printing - as you would expect. However, because it is a threaded rod it tends to screw itself sideways and out of one of the bearings and deeper into the other. Is there some way to prevent the threaded rod from doing this?
comments.author: nick_wallace

comments.text: We put m8 nuts on the ends of the horizontal threaded rod, with some locktite to fix them in place. It does the trick, the rod is no longer moving sideways. You could also use an 8mm smooth rod I suppose.
comments.author: nick_wallace

comments.text: Heh, looks like you had issue with the bed height too?  Mine just barely clears the frame.  Looks like you printed some longer feet to drag it up slightly so that you were actually able to fasten screws under it.  Nice work.  I might have to reprint those anyways (they were made in PLA just to get my machine up and running)...

I broke mine on the maiden flight and HK never stocks them. This is essentially a copy with a few improvements. -slots in cone for venting, not the ugly tip cut off like the original
-better shaped, tighter fitting cutout for the propeller
-better webbing on base from center to outer (original had a large slot hole that made it weak). multiple holes instead of slot hole
*Note: I have not tested to ensure enough airflow will get to the motor to prevent it burning up. I intend to do so at my earliest opportunity. *the most trouble I'm had thus far is getting the 2 screws in without ripping off the bosses. I am thinking about making the screw depth shorter by thickening the material the go through on the cone. Also, there may be other ways to strengthen the 2 bosses I'm not aware of... *2/17/2015: revved both, I beefed up the screw bosses, thickened the web on the cone, and enlarged the screw holes by 0.009 *2/18/2015: I am planning to do a 4 screw version of this to better seat the cone against the base *3/16/2015: updated/revved both parts for better fit to one another.

title: Nintendo 3DS Original Extended Battery Handgrip Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Have one of these and one of these and wish they worked together? Wish no longer! this is a small adapter piece for the original 3DS that snaps into place in the handgrip and snugly fits the extended battery so you can play for hours AND play without hand cramps at the same time! Unfortunately the 3DS does stick out a bit over the handgrip due to the extended battery's height, so this is not quite as comfortable as the handgrip is with the stock battery, but its much better than no grip at all. This adapter probably only fits this specific battery, but you might have luck using it with other handgrips. Cheers!

whatever settings should be fine - it's not a difficult print. It is designed to snap in, so if you notice your first layer is slightly wider (due to smooshing the filament into the bed a bit hard on the first layer) you'll want to remove that with a razor.

description.text: Shed for your best garden friend

  • Buy a PS plate (1000x625x4 mm)
  • Buy 20/20 aluframe (4 pieces 720mm, 2 pieces 466mm, 1 piece 616mm, 1 piece 554mm)
  • Glue the parts using short pieces of filament
  • Screw everything together (100 M4x10, 100 sliding block M4)
  • Place the shed outside, bottom aluframe below base plate of the lawnmower charging station.

• Print left or/and right part.
  • Clean holes with 2,5mm drill (NOT 3mm!)
  • Remove old broken parts.
  • Clear holes in speaker case with 5mm drill - carefully, not too deep!
  • Use file or sand paper to adjust size of head of flat screw. You should be able to rotate this screw with minimal force.
  • Optional: use thread glue to fasten flat screew and nut.
  • Assemble and enjoy :)

author: GigaBajcior

title: Philips VS0080/CM8510, Commodore 1081/1084/1084S monitor controls cover replacement

description.text:
Fix your retro monitor now!  Of the Philips VS0080/CM8510 and Commodore (Amiga) 1081/1084/1084S monitors it is known that the hinges of the covers break. Partly due to a design fault, partly to the material becoming brittle after the years.  
I created this replacement cover and tried to mitigate the design problem.

When printing use a higher infill to and be sure to use supports.
After printing using a fine sandpaper for sanding. Then prime, sand again, spray paint it in the correct color. If you want to keep the original cover, you can also replace the hinges by only printing the hinges. Saw off the hinges of the original cover, then print 2 hinges and saw them to get the right measurements (or use Sketchup to get the right measurements before printing), then glue it to the original cover using epoxy glue. I created this cover as follows:
  • I applied ink to once side of the original cover and made a stamp on it of a piece of paper
  • I scanned it and traced the outline in iDraw (you may use your favorite vector graphics editing tool for that), save it as SVG
  • Then I used this great tutorial ('SVG to SketchUp without Plugins!' https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j9j3xqZ7kg8) to convert the SVG to a 3D format Sketchup can used using Blenderr
  • After loading it in Sketchup is used the pull to create the correct dimensions and copied the hinge and moved it to the correct location

description.text: 25mm aluminum tubing corner fitting
ABS Print at 0.3 layer height 15% infill at 245 bed 110

LM8UU sized printable bushings, which use cheap felt furniture glides as the bearing surface.
Two variants are given:
The first, with 6 glides is designed to fully constrain the linear rod.
The second, with only 4 glides, is designed to constrain the axis against rotation, but not against side motion, and is intended to prevent binding.
This is the same arrangement of bearing surfaces as was used in the original Sells Mendel design, written small and inexpensive.

Vitamins:
Â Â Â Â 4 or 6 Waxman 3/8" Round Felt Pads ( http://www.amazon.com/Waxman-Self-Stick-Round-Brown-8-Inch/dp/B000VYN7CS ) Print, insert felt pads, grease well, use in place of LM8UU. When using the 4 pad (unconstrained) version, make sure that it is rotated correctly on the linear rod, so that the axis is constrained against rotation about the opposite rod, but not constrained against motion toward the opposite rod.

Hand paddles help you learn the right angle and position of hands when practicing proper swimming technique. There are many different kinds of paddles some of which are also used to build upper body strength. Here is a one example of hand paddles that you can print. Novice swimmers should start with smaller paddles to prevent injury as training hard with big paddles combined with bad technique can cause heavy strain on shoulders. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hand_paddle I have a design for finger paddles, too. Thing number 683690. Paddles in the photos (including a hand for scale) are prints of the small version. Normal version is similar, but larger.

Print one for each hand. Just two copies, or if it matters is the botton side or top side of the print facing your hand, then one should be a mirror image of the other. Just like your hands - thumb being on the other side.  
Paddle is tied to a hand from any of the holes with a rubber tube, rubberband, piece of string or maybe even a zip tie or something else. This kind of paddles usually come with a rubber tube that sticks to the small holes in the paddles.  
I used pieces of a old road bike inner tube as attachments. I just forced those through the holes on the paddle. Easy to do (using pliers) and works great. If a little of extra rubber is left dangling on the other side of the paddle, it doesn't really matter. That's how it works with commercial paddles too.

description.text:
This is used to make the conversion of a real life model to a model in TinkerCAD with plasticine. It makes the geometric forms that are found on the site. (www.tinkercad.com) It's used for a project to let 12 year olds learn the design cycle. By encouraging them to prototype and 3D-print their design, they learn from their mistakes and improve the designs. Step 1: The children design, without limits or form restrictions.
Step 2: After they've chosen a design, the restrictions of TinkerCAD are implemented by using the extrudoughs.
Step 3: The design is made in TinkerCAD and 3D-printed
Step 4: The 3D-prints can now be observed and improved to their liking.

description.text: A tablet computer holder, inspired by the iPad stand here. This one is optimized for cooking (seeing the recipe), so it has a couple of special features: a rotating tray at the top, to hold a protective film covering your tablet; and another tray at the bottom, holding a cloth for wiping your fingers clean when needed. In thing files there's also a bit extended version of the 3D-plot SCAD library here. With the new version you can plot surfaces with given thickness, not only flat-bottom objects with plotted top surface.

You can approach this in multiple ways. The simplest is:
1) Print tablet_holder.stl
2) Print tablet_holder_cover_trays.stl. Here I suggest rotating the shafts to lay flat on the bed and use a support structure. Having them stand up caused them to rip away from the bed in my case. Also you can open tablet_holder.scad, modify and render the way you wish. You will need the intermediate result "tablet_holder_base_modified.stl" - I saved the 3D plot rendition and thickened it in Blender. As the last option you can start over by invoking "tabletHolderBase()" in the OpenSCAD.

description.text: These files are parts that I modified for use in making the E-nable RIT 3D printed prosthetic arm. The tricep cuff was modified to address a cracking issue I had after a brief period of use by my first recipient. The forearm cup was modified to reduce weight, and allow a more generic, silicone insert friendly internal shape. The fingers were created to have a more visually compatible look than the Cyborg Beast fingers. These parts are designed for RIT arm v 0.43, but some parts may be compatible with newer versions. These files do not include everything required to make a complete arm. These are only the parts that I modified. The original RIT files are here: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/rit-e-nable-arm-v0-43#!design-information Use of these items require careful implementation of sizing methods that may require consultation with a medical professional. 03/08/2015 - Added left hand versions of tricep cuff, forearm receiver, and palm. 04-18-2015: Updated the tricep cuff to V2 to solve a newly reported cracking issue. http://www.proto3dprinting.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/cuff-update-v2.jpg

Scaling of these parts may cause fitment problems in holes that use Chicago style screws. Specifically, the holes where the finger and thumb proxes attach to the palm may be oversize or undersized depending on scaling. Slightly undersized holes may be opened up to proper diameter by carefully running a drill through the holes. I have found that a 13/64 (.203") drill bit works well. Just be sure that the area around the hole doesn't become too thin. If you have SolidWorks capabilities, you may prefer to use the files I have located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:604380

title: A reproduction of the Mars globe, complete with valleys, plains, and mountains.

description.text:
The STL file was made with PhotoToMesh V6 and a Digital Elevation Model bumpmap of Mars. You can see the biggest mountain of Mars, Olympus Mons, its three close neighbours, Tharsis Montes, and the deep valley Vallis Marineris.  
If you have a higher quality printer than I do then you may be able to see and recognise other landmarks.  
I have exagerated the elevation bump mapping. The tallest mountain should be 0.33mm on a 100mm sphere, I've made it 4mm!

I printed it at only 100mm diameter and 0.2mm layer thickess. It would probably look better at 200mm diameter and 0.1mm layer thickness.  
There is a hole at the northern pole because that was a way to trick the XYZWare into understanding that this is a hollow sphere.  
(I could not upload the hi-res 98MB STL file for some reason, so I uploaded a lower res 56MB file. Let me know if you want the higher res version, contact help at  ransen.com.)

Easy-E is alive and well! This is a simple slide rule to calibrate Esteps. The gauge can be mounted in quite a few different orientations and is designed to snap on to the center groove of 20mm Extrusions. http://youtu.be/-BgdgcUAUXA
http://youtu.be/UBapl4dKNjY

Print out the three parts. The mount fastens to the gauge with an M4x10 screw. The slider/pointer gets slotted in sideways then slid to the bottom of the gauge plate where there is a cutout to rotate the slider to the correct orientation (see back pic.) If the slider hangs, trim & sand the slider slot so that it moves freely.  
Print the included 100mm gauge and pointer (Print @ 100%, no print scaling, only 1:1!) and attach with a little clear tape. Try not to wrap the tape around the parts because it may cause binding.  
Snap the mount in place, snap the filament into the slide and push it so that the pointer rests on 0mm. Call for 75mm to be extruded and then read the gauge after the command is completed.  
Adjust for the over/under extrusion based on the calibration instructions of your printer/controller.  
Because filament, current printer calibration, mount length requirements vary... I have included the autocad files so adjustments can be made.  
Don't forget to post the remixes.  
Enjoy!

title: 3D Printed Year Of The Goat Chopstick Helper

description.text:
Since Chinese New Year is around the corner, and most Chinese are already starting to eat 'Yee Sang' during this festive season. Eating Yee Sang during Chinese New Year is a cultural activity for Chinese living in Singapore and Malaysia. For those who face difficulties in handling chopsticks (especially when you are required to toss the yee sang as high as possible for better fortune and prosperity), I've designed and 3D printed a chopstick helper to better improve your chopstick handling skills...:) Printed via Designex 3D Odyssey X2 (Dual Extruder) 3D Printer.
Material Flex Rubber fused with PLA.
Can be printed with single extruder, as 3D model parts are separated.
2 different models are uploaded as various chopstick designs varies.

description.text: This is a very simple derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6827 -- I've simply redesigned the rod-riders, based on some bushing code I wrote. I am still testing this. No promises. :-)

Obtain: two polished metal rods, probably steel; two bushings that fit the rods. I found stainless steel rods and bronze bushings at my local hardware store. Total cost: less than $10. Print the rod mounting brackets from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2151 Open the cupcake/wobble-arrester.scad file. Edit the parameters to match your configuration. In particular, measure the distance from your mounted rods to your extruder platform. Print two of your customized rod_rider parts. Assemble according to zgbot's directions.

description.text:
This is a replacement for the part called "tobera" on the original bq i3 hephestos. I designed it to guide the cooling air around the nozzle to cool the object from all sides as the standard part only guides cool air to one side of the object.  
You have to print this in ABS as it is way to close to the hot end for a part made of PLA.   
V4 Version did not work! New version V5 fixes a problem inside the thing partly blocking air flow.

comments.text: Too many holes. The volume of holes exceeds the volume of the blower. This nozzle is actually diffusing the air, which reduces cooling. My math says the best combo is 16 evenly spaced 3mm holes. I've been correcting everyone who makes versions of these. I've only seen one done right, but cant find it now.

description.text:
My work light clamp broke and i made the, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27253, lamp base.
Then the foot part of the clamp broke.......
I did a quick design and it worked very well, however i used a steel insert that i had access to in the design of my original part.
I made a second part that is without that insert, and just has a hole.
The part also has a small screw hole, for a more permanent mounting.

I printed mine in ABS, 4 perimeters, .25 infill. The A1 object has the inset for my part ( which you don't have )
The A2 object has a straight hole for the rod. I also used a bit of 220 grit sandpaper, glued to the surface in contact with the desk edge. This gives very good traction to keep the mount from "moving around" RTV Silicone was used to stick the sandpaper down. ( i also did this with the upper part of the lamp base ).

author: pruser

title: Arduino Pro Mini & Compatibles Mount or Holder

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0w0E3Azhj3p This mount was designed to fit Arduino Pro Mini and Pro Mini compatible boards. The PCB slides in from either end and is held in place by friction. The slide gaps in the design will accommodate the thinner style SparkFun Pro Mini PCB as well as the more common and thicker Pro Mini clones PCB's made by Baite and the like. The mount has four screw hole tabs. Enjoy!

I measured my assortment of Arduino Pro Mini and Arduino Pro Mini boards, created a flat mounting plate with four tabs with screw holes for mounting to a surface.  I then attached vertical rails to the base of the mount approximately 7.0mm height (some adjustments were made along the way) figuring for an air gap below the PCB which wires can pass through and can be soldered to the top side or bottom side of the PCB solder pads on all sides of the PCB.  Each rails is approximately 2.5mm in thickness so that a 1.2mm (approximate) groove could be created on each side on the interior of each vertical on the mount allowing the PCB to slide in and hold in place with a little bit of friction.  To accommodate the differing heights of the PCB's found out there in the world of Arduino clones I made sure that the groove height on each rail was approximately 1.5mm so that the thicker PCB's fit as well as the thin SparkFun PCB's fit just fine.

title: Kyosho Blizzard sprocket mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Kyosho Blizzard sprocket mod:
Here's the mod I did for the Kyosho Blizzard srpocket. It prevents snow packing up in the area between the sprocket teeth. When snow packs up there, the part becomes a big ice cylinder, and doesn't drive the caterpillar anymore. The indentations in my design prevents that from happening.
I also included the design for the original part.

Works best with support under the part. I also used a raft but it may not be necassary.
I also used 4 perimeters so the part is very resillient, even when used in the cold (tested to -25°C).
I used 0.1mm layer height for greater accuracy, but 0.2mm is also fine.

description.text:
I would to learn about Gears. Build a Plate with two Pins from
Pin Connectors V3 (Tony Buser), Modified by Emmett Lalish.
I define the Distance between the two Pins to 50mm.
Define two Gears.
A Gear 1 with 10 Teeth.
A Gear 2 with 6 Teeth.
Calulate
r1 + r2 = 50mm
r1 / r2 = 10T / 6T
give r1 = 31.25mm and r2 = 18.75mm
Modul = 6.25 (2xr/T = 2x31.25mm/10)

On Google Play i found a App with Name Zahnradberechnung.

description.text: This is designed to hold six screwdrivers whose shafts are 100mm long or less.  It's very simple in design.

I recommend printing with a significant brim in order to prevent curling.  Additionally, I printed it with 20% infill, as it doesn't need to be super super strong to do its job well.  
Printing it on its top will likely result in a prettier object, although I designed it to print on its back to give the greatest strength in the downward direction.

comments.text: Anyway it can be modded to hold 9??
comments.author: BigRedhawk

comments.text: While it's certainly possible to design a larger model, you end up with tradeoffs.  If I made it three deep to accommodate 9, the print time is 33% longer, which means the possibility of it coming loose from the bed or warping significantly increases.   If I make it wider, I run the risk of running the model right off of my bed, or increasing warping/curling because of my heated bed's nature.
comments.author: BigRedhawk

title: Hand Concept 1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've always wanted a 3D printable robotic hand, and I know you have too.
A while back I decided to take a stab at designing a wire controlled hand. I never got it right, and I'm not sure I have the background to finish it. Here are my basic parts and design files. I am posting them so other people might be inspired to work on this problem. The design files have become unwieldy so I would start from scratch.

You can print, clean, and assemble the hand, and even thread wires ( I would recommend steel or some strong cord ). Unfortunately, the physics won't work out and there aren't enough control points, so you won't be able to do anything interesting besides spray paint it silver and use it (immobile) in your next terminator costume.

comments.text: A right hand would be good for The Force Awakens Luke costumes, which is what I'm planning to do!
comments.author: PlasticJedi

comments.text: One thing your hand design misses would be a thumb.
comments.author: TimothyChronosParaxade

comments.text: Excellent!  Keep it up! 8-)

comments.text: Very Cool!
comments.author: Zomboe

comments.text: You jusr need to Move the wires to the inside of the bend of the fingers instead of passing it through the "bone"
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: The wires actually work, they just usually only move one of the three finger joints.
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: The other problem I was having was that the joints are high friction. When you have one wire controlling three joints, any one of the three joints can bend when the wire is pulled. Usually, just one joint would bend first and then the others might bend later. As far as I can tell human hands kind of bend all three joints evenly. Looking at the robotic hand I linked below, it seems like they use a unique pair of wire for each joint to get around this. It might also be possible to solve the forces so that all three joints bend evenly ?
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: Actually, when you grab onto something, the inner joints move first, then middle, then outer, similar to wrapping a cord/tentacle around a cylinder.
comments.author: mrule

comments.text: this is very cool!  thanks for posting this, even if it isn't working perfectly.  perhaps you'll inspire the next person to come along.

description.text:
Cool looking book case for those mechanics. Printed using the CAD from the Ford Engine Block (link below). The Ford 6 cylinder engine block was printed up to height of 78mm. If you are planning to make this product stop printing at 77-80mm in height. The fan was borrowed off the Toyota Engine CAD (link below). The bookcase rings and fan axle are made by me. The engine block was printed in Orange PLA, took 20-25 hours on the TAZ 4 at a 3mm layer height and at 120mm/s. The fan, and bookcase ratings were also printed at 120 mm/s in a 3mm layer height. Both were printed in ABS. They only took one night. All the parts were joined with a hot glue gun, be cautious of any fumes! Hot glue does slightly melt PLA plastic. Do this in a ventilated area with eye protection. Ford Engine Block http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40257
Toyota Engine (FAN SCALED) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:644933/#files Credit to both these thingiverse suers for uploading their CADS.

The engine block was printed in Orange PLA, took 20-25 hours on the TAZ 4 at a 3mm layer height and at 120mm/s.   
The fan, and bookcase ratings were also printed at 120 mm/s in a 3mm layer height. Both were printed in ABS. They only took one night.  
All the parts were joined with a hot glue gun, be cautious of any fumes! Hot glue does slightly melt PLA plastic. Do this in a ventilated area with eye protection.

comments.text: I did use support for all angles above 50 degrees. However if I were to print it again I don't think support is entirely necessary. Try fro yourself with support. It will be kind of hard to remove though.

title: Fan Foot ($2200 machine makes feet for $10 fan)

description.text:
Are your box fans tipping over all the time making time consuming costly messes?
THERE HAS GOT TO BE A BETTER WAY! These are replacement feet for box fans
(a part seemingly designed to fail universally) Somehow this project exemplifies everything cool about 3D printing while simultaneously shining an absurd white hot light on its impracticality... The machine cost $2200, the filament $50/kg, it took me a couple hours to make the sub-millimeter accurate model (parts, boolean, fixing the mesh, export, import, slice), and it took about 2 hours to print four feet in fast mode from the MakerWare software. BUT HEY, LOOK! I MADE FAN FEET AND YOU CAN TOO!

I included an .stl model of a single foot and a .thing file for a pair of feet saved from MakerWare 2.0.2.9.
They need to be printed on their sides with raft and support. 
I printed them using the low settings (I like to print to file on the memcard so my machine doesn't have to drive the machine - that way if I do something taxing or stupid on my computer chat causes a hang, crash, or whatever it won't screw up the print).
Print them, yank them off the raft, pry out the supports and clip into your fan!  
Now your fan can stand tall like the proud fan that it is with these 100% American designed box fan feet.

remixed_from.author: spot1984
remixed_from.title: Replicator 2 front loading quick change spool mount

title: New Improved Rep 2 front loading spool mount

description.text:
Have you ever wondered why they put the darn spool mounts on the back of the Replicator 2? Have you ever wondered why the clips for the spools are so tight? It's a nightmare to change the filament on these awesome machines, especially if they are on a shelf or desk with limited space. This clip-on quick-change front spool mount fixes all that! It allows easy, quick, no fuss changes of the filament FROM THE FRONT without having to move the Replicator 2!
[Copied from spot1984 and i agree]

Improvements
-Changed diameter of the spool arm to fit all types of filament spool from 30mm to 100mm - so no longer support just the makerbot spool [whoop whoop]
-Strengthened the length of the entire front mount which includes the spool arm
-Strengthen the filament holding tube holes [my hole clips broke immediately on the previous version] Suggestions
  • print in black pla b/c it is the stongest colour apparently
  • print in black b/c it blends into the makerbot and it looks like an original part
  • print in black b/c it hides any imperfections from the print
    • Settings
    Raft yes
    Supports yes
    It comes out looking ugly but the supports strip away very easy and leave a clean part
    I left the supports in the spool arm b/c they give strength and you dont see them
    Its a tight fit on the plate so use my 'thing' layout for a gteed print shell 1
    infill 100%
    layer 0.34 [i wasnt concerned by lack of detail]
    I have printed and tested
    works brilliantly
    so easy to keep an eye on the spool for tangles etc
    does not obstruct view
    the guide tube holes were too tight for me but i didnt widen b/c they were firm for spot1984 so i just left it [easy to make bigger with a drill but cant make smaller ;) basically this is just a copy of what spot1984 did so dont give me any credit

description.text:
This is a 3D scan of the statue of the Roman emperor Trajan (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajan) in the New Carlsberg Glyptotek museum in Copenhagen, Denmark.
I found the model here: http://www.123dapp.com/catch/Copenhagen-Glyptotek-statue-the-emperor-Trajan/3489610

author: 3DWP

title: FaceCube: Copy Real Life with a Kinect and 3D Printer

description.text: This project is documented at my blog http://eclecti.cc/hardware/facecube-copy-real-life-with-a-kinect-and-3d-printer , but I will summarize it here. This project is a tangent off of something cool I've been hacking on in small pieces over the last few months. I probably would not have gone down this tangent had it not been for the recent publication of Fabricate Yourself. Nothing inspires me more than when someone does something cool and then releases only a description and pictures of it. Thus, I've written FaceCube, my own open source take on automatic creation of solid models of real life objects using the libfreenect python wrapper, pygame, NumPy, MeshLab, and OpenSCAD. The real magic comes from when you take advantage of all that OpenSCAD has to offer. Make a copy of yourself frozen in carbonite, put your face on a gear, or make paper weights shaped like your foot. This is also where the name FaceCube comes from. My original goal going into this, I think at my roommateâ€™s suggestion, was to create ice cube trays in the shapes of peopleâ€™s faces. This can be done very easily in OpenSCAD, involving just subtracting the face object from a cube.

The process is currently multi-step, but I hope to have it down to one button press in the future. First, run facecube.py, which brings up a psychedelic preview image showing the closest 10 cm of stuff to the Kinect. Use the up and down arrow keys to adjust that distance threshold. Pressing spacebar toggles pausing capture, to make it easier to pick objects. Click on an object in the preview to segment it out. Everything else will disappear; clicking elsewhere will clear the choice. You can still use the arrow keys while it is paused and segmented to adjust the depth of what you want to capture. You can also use the H and G keys to adjust hole filling, to smooth out noise and fill small holes in the object. If the object is intended to have holes in it, press D to enable donut mode, which leaves the holes open. Once you are satisfied, you can press P to take a screenshot or S to save the object as a PLY format point cloud. You can then open the PLY file in MeshLab to turn it into a solid STL. I followed a guide to figure out how to do that and created a filter script attached below. To use it, click Filters -> Show current filter script, click Open Script, choose meshing.mlx, and click Apply Script. You may have to click in the preview, but after a few seconds, it will say that it Successfully created a mesh. You can click Render -> Render Mode -> Flat Lines to see what it looks like. You can then click File -> Save As, and save it as an STL. You can probably get better results if you manually pick the right filters for your object, but this script will be enough most of the time. You can then open the STL in OpenSCAD or Blender and scale it and modify to your heartâ€™s (or printerâ€™s) content. Since all of the cool kids are apparently doing it, Iâ€™ve put this stuff into a GitHub repository. Go ahead and check it out, errâ€¦ git clone it out. The facecube.py script requires the libfreenect from the unstable branch, and any recent version of pygame, numpy, and scipy. Youâ€™ll need any recent version of MeshLab or Blender after that to do the meshing. Iâ€™ve been using this on Ubuntu 10.10, but it should work without much trouble on Windows or OS X. The latest code will be on git, but if you are averse to it for whatever reason, I've attached the script and the meshlab filter script below. git clone [email protected]:nrpatel/FaceCube.git

Update #1: Bug fix in the Arduino program use version 1_0a This is a laser projector (or POV display) based on 12 mirrors for displaying any alpha numeric characters. The projector as a clock in action can be seen at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KLzSlPYd9MY. Usually the adjustment of the mirrors is very difficult and time demanding for a rotated mirror based laser projector. With this 3D-printed mirror wheel every mirror can be simply adjusted with a screw. It allows to use one or more lasers but the arduino I used isn't fast enough for more than two laser. The character size could be up to 12x8 dots even I use in my program only 8x5. For the initial adjustment the program incorporates with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:480487 but there are of course other possibilities. The projector has a large container on top this can be filled e.g. with coins in order to give it the necessary weight otherwise it starts to "walk around"

Everything is printed with 0.25mm without support. The side panel where treated with acetone in order to make them transparent.  
All materials in the attached BOM. If you want to build one use a Fan with ball bearing (I didn't)

comments.text: So each mirror is adjusted to make an individual pixel (dot) from top to bottom, correct? How are you moving the characters horizontally? My guess is, it is timing the pulse to a specific area of the mirror which changes the reflection angle, thus moving it left or right accordingly. Thanks for sharing this project, it is fascinating :-)
comments.author: briankb

comments.text: Yes you're correct in both. In the horizontal it's a timing matter. There is a sensor below the mirror wheel which tells the electronics when a mirror comes in the laser area. From then on the laser is switched off and on to generate the horizontal line of dots for the characters. In my case a dot is about 10 microseconds long. If the laser wouldn't be switched off and on a solid line would appear.

author: ftopete

description.text: Paper napkin holder for 6" x 6" napkins.

Paper napkin holder for 40 to 50, standard six-inch square paper napkins. The basic design sits on the table. I also made one that hangs on the wall. I haven't tested it. The tab doesn't look strong enough to survive for long, but I'll update this project if there is a need. That wall mount file includes a tall, thin "sacrificial" bar so the extruder doesn't hover over the that upper tab, melt and distort it.
The bar gives the small upper section a little time to cool between layers, as the extruder moves back and forth between them.
Fan cooling might be another option. The STLs appear to have some weird vertical lines at the edge of the diamond shapes, but I couldn't find any defects and they printed without error. Plan on 3 hours, 77 grams ABS, 0.3mm layers, medium speed with an Afinia printer. A Metric version of the table-style is included.
BTW.... Scaling up by a factor of 25.4 will scale any SAE (inches) file up to the metric equivalent to suit printers that require metric dimensions.

description.text:
Printable anemometer - clips onto a cell phone (designed for a Nexus 5, could easily be modified to fit a different phone); the phone detects rotations of an added rare earth magnet.
The beginnings of an Android app for reading the meter are here: https://github.com/berkenbu/Anemometer

Print one of each:
  • anemometer_phone_mount
  • anemometer_top_rotor
  • anemometer_rotor_bottom
  • anemometer_magnet_holder
    • Also required:
  • magnet - I used a cylindrical, 8mm diameter rare earth magnet from the hardware store
  • ball bearing - I used a 6mm OD, 3mm ID one from a toy helicopter
  • axle - I used a 3mm dia machine screw with its head removed
    • The 'phone_holder' has a cylindrical hole of 6mm diameter that I used to install a small ball bearing (from a broken toy helicopter) - this might need to be adjusted if you have a different bearing.
    I used a 3mm machine screw with the head removed and matching nuts and washer (for 'sandwiching' the bearing - the rotor and magnet holder just screw on) as an axle - something else could be improvised... I split up the main rotor into two parts to be able to print it without supports: the top and three bottom 'cup segments' are to be glued onto the top. The github for the app is given in the main description - it is very much work in progress. At the point of this writing, it will display RPMs of the rotor (plus a scrolling recent history graph), but not actual wind speed. One would need to calibrate for actual wind speed measurements, possibly with an existing, calibrated anemometer, or a source of known, constant speed wind.
    The app was written in Android studio and should compile without additional libraries - there is a pre-compiled apk in the folder 'app'.
Feed your Poros with this snacks, and they'll become fat an big.

Open in OpenSCAD and click on F6 to renderize. When it finish, go to:
File: Export: as STL ( or the type of file that you use ). And enjoy it!

author: Dvogonen

description.text:
Sarrus linkage linear bearing
This is an implementation of the Sarrus linkage that may be useful for reprap type machines.  It is made from ABS printed on my repstrap, with 1/16" (1.6 mm) brass rods for the hinge pins and 4-40 screws to hold the spine sections together.  The hinge pin holes were chased with a 1/16 drill bit, and the screw holes with a 1/8" bit.  The two ends are made of one center block cut in half with a saw, and there are some other holes that were drilled rather than printed.
It has a total swing of 100 mm.  This is set by the length of the spine, and could easily be 110 mm.  It moves very smoothly, and was stiffer than I thought it would be.  The center block only moves down about 0.2mm with a 460 gram payload.  Interestingly the droop is about the same over the whole range of motion. It stays well within 0.2mm of a straight line as it moves.
A payload (extruder?) could mount on the central block, which could be widened.

comments.text: Just wondering, what keeps the center block from getting stuck on those brackets used to attach the spine blocks together?

comments.text: The swing arms constrain the motion so the center block doesn't touch the center brackets.

This is my version of Prusa's I3 3D printer that I have modified to include all the features I wanted. It is fully enclosed so that the heat of the hot end and heated bed heat the build chamber. It also has auto bed leveling which uses a solenoid to activate the Z axis end stop switch. The printer can be operated with an external computer but also has a Raspberry PI to run Octoprint. All of the wires have been run thru cable chains or cable covers to eliminate the possibility of the wires being snagged by moving parts. This is a work in progress. As I prepare the files I will upload them. If you would like to see a run through of the printer and it's features you can watch the video. http://youtu.be/t7iFNazMBQU
The frame of the printer is laser cut 6 mm plywood and smoked acrylic with 3 mm acrylic for the door and windows the rest is 3D printed.

title: Necklace Stand with spider web at top

description.text: This a necklace stand I designed to hold 16 necklaces. I wanted to make it a little more interesting to look at, so I added the spider web design at the top. I used a 11.5" long 3/8" oak dowel for the support, but you can print a plastic dowel if you prefer from the included file. The widest part is slightly less than 200mm. I also included a test part so you can check whether the hole prints the correct size on your printer. I still had to sand the dowel a little so it had a nice slip fit & would turn easily. There is an updated version of this design located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1054244

Print the test part 1st to make sure the hole will be the correct size.
If it needs adjusting on your printer, create a new test part by changing the P38ID variable size in the file TestDowelAndHoleSize.scad & reprint. If you are going to use a 3/8" dowel, you do not need to print the plastic dowel part. After you are happy with the sizes being correct.

  • Print the NecklaceStandTopWithStraightHooks_rev12_repaired.stl (this part took 3 hours & 50 minutes on my printer & weighs 2.2oz)

  • Print the NecklaceStandBottom_repaired.stl or receate this file changing the P38ID variable in the corresponding openscad file
    (this part took 1 hour & 30 minutes on my printer & weighs 0.8oz)

  • If you want to use the plastic dowel, which I made 8 sided, print the length you want. You can print the dowel diagonally on your build plate if it will fit better that way. The stl files are generated that way. I used a 11.5" long 3/8" Oak dowel instead of using the plastic part, since I had some & thought it would be better than plastic. I have not tested using the plastic dowels, but included this in case someone wanted to use all plastic.
    • I printed this in PLA at layer height of .2mm & infill of .2 & brim of 4 using Slic3r 0.99.

description.text: Has to be printed supporttyp: touching buildplate and a rim.

This dust shoe attaches to the X axis gantry instead of the spindle or spindle mount.  This allows the spindle to move in the Z axis without raising or lowering the dust shoe.  It attaches to the back side of the X axis gantry in the slot hole that is unused.  I used a bolt and wing nut. I wanted a shoe that did not require any mods to my Shapeoko 2 or the spindle mount. It will print on a 6" x 9" (150 x 250 mm) printer bed (Flashforge or Original Makerbot or clones)  The shoe bottom and hose adapter snap into the shoe on mine so no glue was required.  The mount was super glued on.  The hose adapter fits a standard shop vac hose.  
I have included another version of the mount part that has a relief cut into it to allow clearance for a nut so you can put a nut on the mounting bolt so you do not need any tools when using wing nuts  
I have also included the obj file so if anyone needs or wants to make changes to the Dust Shoe.  The file can be edited in most 3d graphics programs like Blender.

description.text:
This is a 3D scan of the Laurentian sow (http://www.mlahanas.de/Greeks/Mythology/LaurentianSow.html) a sculpture at the New Carlsberg Glyptotek museum in Copenhagen, Denmark.
I found the scan here: http://www.123dapp.com/catch/Copenhagen-Glyptotek-statue-The-Laurentian-Sow/3492156
I edited the model wih MeshMixer: I made a plane cut, used a smooth brush and scaled the model up for 3D printing. http://www.3dwp.nl

A scale model of the sculpture "Cloud Gate" in Chicago's Millennium Park. I made this with TinkerCad using my own shape generator, "Bezier Bean". This model and shape generator are publicly available on TinkerCAD: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7ECRdzjIHsa

Print this model upside-down with supports and rafts.  After printing, cut the supports off with a razor blade.  On my Makerbot Replicator, I used 25% infill to prevent sagging and standard quality because the higher bead size of standard quality yields a shinier finish.  
A bold idea would be to print this in stainless, then polish the result to a mirror shine.

comments.text: Nice Model. I had no idea it was called something other than "The Bean". Now, how can we chrome one?
comments.author: smokeandlights

comments.text: It should be really straightforward to adapt it for 3D printing in steel, and if you like I will make a version suitable for this and post it here.  All I'd do is make it a hollow shell by scaling down the TinkerCAD model a bit and then add a couple of small holes at the bottom where brass can be poured into the hollow shell.  The catch is that if you want a mirror finish like the real thing, the only way to do that is going to be to buff the result with a dremel tool and some rogue.  Plating a rough surface will only yield a plated rough surface.
comments.author: smokeandlights

comments.text: Thanks, but don't do it for my benefit. I was mostly kidding around. It would be neat to see, though.

comments.text: I had issues with my cheap axial fan as well. Would not start at anything below 100%.  Centrifugal fans are quieter and I believe they work better when you have back pressure such as a nozzle.  The fan I have was less than $5. It starts consistently at 35% speed.

author: migra

description.text: This long-spinning top has a spring suspension built into the bottom, making for extra smooth running - and smoother running means longer spin times. Like it's cousin (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:681860) it prints in a single piece upside-down.

Printed in PLA, 0.2mm layers, 3 perimeters, 3 bottom layers, 4 top layers, and 50% infill.  No supports needed.  The spiral suspension spring makes a bit of a rats nest on the underside but it seems to clean up pretty well by the time it gets to the top layers.  You'll probably need to run an x-acto knife through the spiral to cut away any stray strands of filament.
